lines.text: Are we to be abducted every day in Iceland?
We'll observe one minute of silence in memory of a great scientist, even if he was a blasted thief.
I don't sleep. I hate those little slices of death.
Whom did you intend to take along besides this young man?
The big Icelander.
Then I'll be very useful. He doesn't understand a word of English.
Someone is walking up there. I heard footsteps, human footsteps.
Madam, since the beginning of time, all women have heard footsteps "up there."
Poor Sir Oliver, stuck with a woman. If only you could see your face.
That's my consolation, madam, I don't have to look at it. You do.
You won't find anything edible in there.
Why not? The Chinese eat eggs over 400 years old.

[after discovering Professor Göteborg dead in his hotel room]
Why didn't they tell us at the desk?
Hotels rarely advertise the fact that there are corpses lying around.
Oliver, you're seriously ill.
I am seriously well!

[in Icelandic]
There is a tunnel on this side.
He says there's a tunnel on the other side.

[in Icelandic]
And they slant downhill, and we can walk them.
Slanting downhill, but walkable.

[in Icelandic]
Excuse me, madam, can you tell me, where do we go now, what do we do now?
Sir Oliver, you're not going to listen to a murderer?
Never interrupt a murderer, madam.
I resent that bourgeois classification. I'll spare your lives. You have my word of honor.
Give me your hand on that.
[Sir Oliver throws salt into Count Saknussemm's eyes]
A bourgeois trick. So sorry.

[singing]
Here's to the prof of geology. Master of all nat'ral history. Rare boy he, and rare boys we, To know such a big curiosity.
Sir Oliver, in the name of the whole student body, in gratitude for the knowledge you have imparted to us...
That's enough obituary prose. An inkwell I presume. A very handsome thing. Hellish to dust.
There'll never be a better moment than today. I'm going to tell him about our feelings for each other. He'll say yes almost inadvertently.
Well, what if he says no, advertently?
I wonder if Madam Goetabaug will change her mind at the last moment.
You make my mouth water.
Hans is tying the rope on her.
I'm a fool. I should have told him to tie her to one of the mules and send her back where she belongs.
In what language would you have told him that, Sir Oliver?
All right, she may be of some use in that respect. Then there's always the blessed chance the rope may break.
Do you realize we know less about the earth we live on than about the stars and the galaxies of outer space? The greatest mystery is right here, right under our feet!
Come here, take a look.
[Alec cowers when he sees how high on the mountain they are]
Did you expect a flight of stairs with a red carpet?
I... I neglected to tell you, sir, I... I have a nervous fear of heights.
Well, you'll get over that after the first million fathoms or so.
A field of force that snatches gold away! This is it, this is it! The junction of magnetic forces from the North Pole to the South Pole - the center of the earth!
Where are you eating tonight?
U-uh... this being Tuesday, I-I'm not eating.
Oh?
I-I find it very healthy to... to eat only every other night.
To save what we can, I insist that we leave these regions at once.
You insist? As a matter of fact, he's bloody well right. Let's be off.
Your entire presence is a constant criticism of me. I'm tired of it, I've had enough!
You've had enough! Well, let me tell you, you... you dried up walnut of a man, if anyone's had enough, it's me!
It's *I*.
After all, we... we did hit the center of the earth.
It hit us, laddie.
You know, it's one thing to spend ones days and nights with a man under the earth, another under one roof in Scotland.
Well, ehh... what do you propose?
Oh, that's not a word I'd bandy about, Professor.
What did I say? Which word?
I THOUGHT it would catch in your throat.

[in Icelandic]
The woman in room number 29, she said she wants to talk to you.
Tell him to stop jabbering and go shopping.
Uhh, what about lamps?

[in Icelandic]
The woman in room number 29, she said...
Ah, uh, lamps... lamps. What about... ah... picks?
Thank you, Scartaris!

[in Icelandic]
O, madam, will you all come down here where the boy fell. It is so wonderfully beautiful down there.
What's happened now? What's he saying?
He said we should go back to where Alec fell.

[in Icelandic]
He is guilty.

[in Icelandic]
Hans, let him go.

[in Icelandic]
Madam, the tunnel lies straight upwards, but there is a big rock in the way and sadly we can't move it. Only a landslide could move it.

[in Icelandic, to his duck]
My Gotrun, have you been lonely?
Young man with the gold tooth, I'll give you more gold if you guide us to Reykjavik.

[in Icelandic]
Ahh, yes, yes, yes, Reykjavik.
You... take us... to Reykjavik.
[in front of a church in Edinburgh after a service]
Miss Jenny! I saw you turn pale when the Domini spoke of those in peril at the far ends of the earth.
Far ends of the earth - at least that would be somewhere.
Did you get your injuries when the volcano blew up, in the hot lava?
Oh no. No, it happened in Edinburgh at our wedding.
He was in such a hurry leaving the church, he fell all the way down the steps.
Oh! You poor wee bride. After all that waiting. It's been no marriage for you at all.
You underestimate Alec.

[after finding crumbling loaves of ancient bread]
Stale bread. We must speak to the baker.
A dimetrodon!
If I had my gun, we'd have fresh meat for dinner.
That's what he's saying. He's a flesh eater.
We're scientists, aren't we? That's one society where frayed cuffs don't matter. We've ALL had 'em.
There's no need to lose that patient voice with me, Professor.
Would you rather I use an impatient voice?
Professor Linderbrook, I am a member of this expedition, and as such I intend to report any observation I make.
Alec, put it down in the record that a member of the expedition reports... rats in the attic. Lights out!
Listen, young foreigner, I don't have to steal what belongs to me. You're in my world now.
Tired minds don't plan well. Sleep first, plan later.
the spirit of Man can not be stopped.
